preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-6.8 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with full sun receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start Tomato seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-04-15 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.25 inches deep with 24 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-04-15 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water Tomato deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect Tomato weekly for common zone 5a-7a pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting Tomato approximately 75 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Tomato at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

plant_groupings.spacing_notes: Plant tomatoes in the north side, spaced 24 inches apart. Lettuce and basil can be interspersed between tomato plants, with lettuce at 6 inches and basil at 8 inches apart
Place dragon fruit on the south side of the garden, spaced 12 inches apart to allow for proper growth and sunlight exposure

general_tips: Start seedlings indoors 4-6 weeks before the last frost date (around May 15th) to give them a head start on the growing season.
Choose disease-resistant tomato varieties such as 'Early Girl' or 'Patio' to combat common issues in our region.
Lettuce and other leafy greens prefer cooler temperatures, so plant them in early spring or late summer/early fall when it's around 60-70°F (15-21°C).
Basil is a warm-season crop and should be planted after the last frost date. Make sure to provide it with full sun (at least 6 hours of direct sunlight) and well-draining soil.
Dragon Fruit requires a long growing season, so plant it in late spring or early summer when the soil has warmed up to at least 65°F (18°C).
In our region's temperate climate, be prepared for occasional frosts and freezes. Use row covers or bring potted plants under cover if necessary.
Water your plants deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth and make them more resistant to drought.
